text:
Sweet...yes.  Spicy...yes.  Sticky...no Very good flavor but I had the same problem other reviewers mentioned about the sauce not thickening up. I will make it again with the following changes: 1. Dredging the chicken strips in flour before sauteing, which will help them brown better and help thicken the sauce. 2. Saute on med.-high heat instead of medium. The heat called for in the recipe is not enough to sear the chicken. 3. Simmer the sauce while I am preparing the chicken, then add to the chicken as called for. Because, it took much longer than 8-10 minutes to reduce the sauce, and the chicken dried out. I should add my husband loved this recipe. The flavors are good. Thanks.

text:
A-MA-ZING...simply amazing!  I followed the advice of other reviewers and dredged the chicken in flour first.  Then I sauteed an onion and some peppers and set aside.  Next was to quickly sear/brown bite-sized pieces of chicken (you want that crunchy coating) and added the sauce and cooked veggies to simmer.  For the hot sauce you MUST use Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce (Rooster Sauce).  It MAKES the dish.  My chicken was sticky, sweet and spicy just the way it was supposed to be.  What an amazing flavor profile.  I'm thrilled with this recipe!

text:
AWESOME AWESOME chicken. Used ground ginger and 1 tbs. of hot sauce but could hardly taste it. If you like spicey, use both. My came out VERY sticky! Here's what I did: cut up chicken into small chuncks, put in bag with flour and shake until lightly coated. Put in frying pan at #8 of 10...very hot, until started to really brown. Took several minutes. Then I added the sauce, tossed, dropped to #3 and put lid on until rice was done, probably 15 minutes. Continue to use the same pan even though the chicken sticks and burns on the botton!!!! All that stuff makes it sticky! Will make again and again!

text:
I followed the recipe pretty much exactly.  I did notice that when I poured the sauce over the chicken, it seemed to be taking way too long to reduce.  I was also afraid of over-cooking the chicken, so I took it out of the pan.  When the sauce reduced to a thick molasses constistancy, I put the chicken back in to coat it.  I think the juices of the chicken were keeping the sauce from reducing properly and I wanted the chicken juice in the chicken, not the sauce.  This came out good and we enjoyed it, but the chicken was a trifle dry.  Next time I'll remove the chicken as soon as it's browned, reduce the sauce and then add the chicken back.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Really delicious, tastes like something from a local restaurant that we really like. I did make several modifications though. I lightly floured the chicken and then seared it in a pan sprayed with Pam on medium high, and sprayed the chicken while cooking instead of using oil. Turned down to low after chicken was browned before adding the sauce. I used 3 Tbps of soy sauce, an extra tablespoon of brown sugar because we like our meat sweet, and used squeeze tubes of garlic and ginger which gave the sauce a thicker consistancy and made it super easy to cook & thicken, it was finished in minutes! Also, I added a chopped sauteed vidalia onion, so good with the sauce! Served over rice.

text:
I try lots of new recipes and this is the best one I've tried in a long time.  It scored a huge homerun with hubby and all three kids (5, 8, 11).  It is a rare feat to find something that everyone raves about.  Just the right mix of sweet and spicy. So quick, simple and made with ingredients I always have on hand.  I'll be making this over and over again. FYI:  I doubled the sauce and dredged the chicken in flour, salt and pepper before frying.  I cooked the chicken in two batches, cooked it until completely done, then added 1/2 of the sauce. It "stickied" up quickly and I didn't need to cook it the extra 8 minutes the recipe calls for.  I think it might have burnt if I had done that.  My 11-year old couldn't stop raving - "Mom, this is like the stuff you get at the Chinese restaurant only 10 times better!" Give this one a try!  UPDATE:  My kids asked for this a second time this week and I obliged!  I tripled the sauce this time thinking I'd like some extra sauce to serve over rice.  BIG MISTAKE - it thickened up too much and wasn't saucy enough to serve over rice.  AND it also completely changed the taste and texture - the sauce was overwhelming and the chicken was "goopy" rather than "sticky" like the last time I made it.  We were all disappointed with the way it turned out tonight. I will stick with the way I made it the first time.

text:
Exactly what I have been looking for in a asian type recipe.  My 12 year old son loved it - as did all of us.  After reading the other reviews I did tweak the recipe and it turned out perfect.  We like a lot of sauce, so I doubled the sauce and cut the amount of chicken in half.  I did put the chicken in flour first like other readers suggested.  Also, since so many had problems with the sauce thickening, I made up the sauce in a bowl and then added about 1/2 tbls of corn starch mixed in with about 1/4 cup water.  I mixed this into the sauce before I cooked it.  It turned out perfect.  I also adjusted the amount of hot sauce (used asian chilie sauce), garlic and ginger to our taste.  I also cooked up a frozen bag of asian type (stir fry) vegtables and added them to the chicken and sauce at the end.  Added water chestnuts too, which were so good in the sauce.  Can't wait to make this again!  My son is so picky, so when he eats a whole bowl of anything, you know it is good!  Someone said the soy sauce taste is very strong, and it is, but we like salty and soy sauce.  However, next time I might cut back on the soy sauce a bit.   Enjoy!

Very good.  Place the meat in a bowl with 3 T. cornstarch and 1 T. water.  Toss and work it in so all of the cornstarch is absorbed. WOW! Thanks Kate for this awesome recipe! I only used 2 chicken breast halves but kept the remainder of the ingredients the same. I shook the chicken strips with 1/2 cup cornstarch in a bag and let them rest for a few minutes before frying them in a preheated skillet with veg oil. I used Sriracha sauce (rooster sauce) for the hot sauce.
I served the chicken and sauce over hot steamed rice. I served Green Bean Amandine on the side (recipe from this site). Next time I'll serve a side green salad with "Famous Japanese Restaurant Style Salad Dressing" from this site. A must is to have watermelon slices on the dinner table. Watermelon cools the tongue and cleans the palate.

I always double the sauce and sprinke the finished plates with toasted sesame seeds prior to serving just for a little something extra.  You can adjust the heat level to suit your preference and this seems to be a dish that almost everyone likes.  Sugar snap peas are a good side with this.

Yum, thanks for the post. I added a couple of Tbsp more brown sugar to sauce as I used "naturally brewed" soy sauce which seems to have a stronger taste that I felt needed to be mellowed a bit with the sugar.
Before I stir fry chicken, I always dredge it in some cornstarch and let it sit for about 5-10 minutes before cooking. It makes the chicken VERY tender and thickens whatever sauce you add to pan after it has cooked for a few minutes.

text:
Absolutely delicious, complex flavor! I think fresh ginger really makes the sauce (I'm not usually a ginger fan, but it tasted great!) and I used only 1 T of Frank's RedHot. Perfect spice amount for me - not hot but added a little kick and boosted the flavor. The sauce didn't thicken on it's own for me either (there's no thickening agent..). Many of the other reviewers suggested coating the chicken with flour, but I am watching my calories, so I just added a tablespoon of cornstarch (mixed with a bit of water first) to the pan after it had simmered for about 5 minutes. Thickened immediately and became very sticky.  The boyfriend loved it and coworkers complimented the smell of the leftovers! Will be making this again for sure!

I make the sauce and let it simmer till somewhat thick.  For the chicken chunks make a batter of 1c. cornstarch, 1/4c. soy sauce and 2 eggs...mixture will be thick, dip chicken in and fry till brown and crispy.  After finding this batter this is all I ever use for my Chinese recipes.  I serve several chicken chunks over rice and pour the sauce over everything. Out of this world!!

This was sensational! I took the advice of other reviewers and dredged the chicken in flour. I then cut up some bell pepper and onion and sauteed those in a little oil. Then I took them out of the pan and added a little bit more oil and browned the chicken. Then I added everything back in and simmered it. I will make this again and again because my husband and I both LOVED it!

text:
Awesome! The only reason I dropped a star was because of the necessity of changing the recipe in order to allow the sauce to thicken. I followed top reviewers' advice of dredging the chicken in flour, browning it first at a pretty high heat, then removing the chicken and cooking the sauce in the same pan, deglazing it and getting all that yummy brown chicken flour off the bottom. It thickened right up and tasted incredible! I also added 1/2 to 1 cup veggie water (from cooking veggies to have on the side), to stretch the sauce out a bit without just doubling ingredients and thus making it too intense. It was a great idea and I would definitely do this again -- we like sauce. :) Also, I don't have hot sauce and we aren't huge on real spicy stuff, but I added a few shakes of red pepper flakes and it gave it just enough of a kick without burning our mouths. Even my picky husband loved it, and my 14-month-old too! :)

Oh, YES!!  We loved this!!  I made the full recipe of sauce for just two chicken breasts and I thought it was just the right amount of sauce.  Because so many reviewers had trouble getting the sauce to thicken, I made it in a saucepan early in the afternoon.  I simmered it for 8 minutes; then let it sit at room temperature until dinner.  I browned/cooked the chicken, poured the sauce over and heated through. Thick sauce, and no chance of over-cooking the chicken!  I was a little concerned about the soy sauce, so I only used 3 T. and I used 1 T. of hot sauce (Frank's).  It was just right!  Thank you!  We'll be making this one again for sure!!!

Sweet, Check! Sticky, Check! Spicy, Check! 
This recipe was deeeelish!!! I made the following adjustments: 5 tbl brown sugar, 3 tbl honey, i used minced garlic instead of fresh chopped out of pure laziness, and omitted the ginger completely (didn't have any in the pantry) I made these adjustments due primarily to the fact of what I had on hand, second the 2 tbl of hot sauce (I used tobasco sauce) was way too hot for me thus why I "uped" the honey and sugar to tae away that nostril burn every time I stirred... As far as cooking adjustments, yes I lightly coated cubed chicken in flour like previous reviews had suggested and used medium high heat to brown the meat in a dash of preheated veg oil, reduced the heat to medium low added the sauce, covered and simmered for about 15 minutes while I made the rice.... DELICIOUS recipe served over rice! Next time I may cook some sugar snap peas to mix in that would be delightful! Thank you so much Kate for this wonderful recipe! Five stars all around!

text:
A wonderful recipe with just enough "bite"!  I did make some "minor" changes based on our own preferences.  Since I dislike ginger, I eliminated it and made up for some flavor by adding sesame oil to the oil when I browned the chicken.  (I removed the chicken while I prepared the sauce.)  The sesame oil's smoky flavor was a plus.  Because I like "crunch" in my Asian dishes, I added a drained can of diced water chestnuts to the sauce once it was reduced, added the chicken again and heated the mixture for another few minutes.  I served it over scallion flavored rice with steamed broccoli on the side.  It was a delicious change.  My only negative is that there wasn't enough sauce.  Next time I make it, I will double the amount of the sticky goodness!

text:
I use this sauce for Asian chicken wings. Here's what I do: 1) In a plastic bag, mix 1 teaspoon each of salt and pepper to 1 cup of AP flour. Put all chicken pieces inside, coat well, and let stand for at least 1/2 hour. Deep fry at 360 F. 
2) If making a lot, put cooked wings in an oven proof bowl in a preheated 170 F. oven.   
3) Add at least 1 teaspoon of crushed red pepper flakes to the sauce and warm to about 130 F. in microwave. Stir and let stand ~~ keeping warm.
4) Pour sauce over wings and toss to coat.

text:
Yum! To quote my hubby's EXACT words: "This tastes like Kung Pao Chicken!" I'm not a fan of Asian foods (I like some, but not most). I have also never tried Kung Pao Chicken before. I msut say, if this is anything like it, I'd be in for a real treat! My chicken was a little sweet, a LOT spicy and super sticky! To achieve this, I did make a slight modification. After cutting up my chicken, I placed it in a large Zip-lock bag, added ~ 1/4 c. of AP flour, s&p'd generouslly and shook like crazy lol! I then heated my oil (medium-high to ensure a super hot skillet) and browned my chicken really well (this took a few minutes). I then added my already mixed sauce ingredients, left the heat as is for a minute or two and then reduced it to "3" and started timing. The flouring step and high heat (to allow everything to bubble / boil slightly) helped thicken my sauce nicely. NOTE: Kate does not specify whether to use Tobasco hot sauce or hot chile sauce (i.e. Sriracha). I chose the latter and was very pleased with the end result. Served with honey roasted red potatoes (STEPHNDON), this was a nice meal. My hubby suggested serving this over sticky rice next time (we didn't care for potatoes on the side, but because they seemed to complement this entree and we've had rice a LOT lately, I gave them a try). Thanks SO much for sharing Kate. I can't believe I waited this long to try your recipe! :-)

I made two chicken bottoms (with skin) with this recipe. I floured the chicken and seared it till crispy on both sides. I removed the chicken from the fire, placed in a baking pan over sliced potato rounds, and poured the sauce into the frying pan. I cooked it for a couple of minutes until thick and then poured it over the chicken and potatoes. I baked it tightly covered at 350 for 1 hour, and then uncovered it, raised the temp to 400 and baked for 20 minutes. It was AMAZING! I did not change a thing in the sauce - it was heavenly. I used Frank's Red Hot, and because it was so spicy, I may use a little less next time. But omg, it was sweet, spicy, and sticky all right! Definitely a keeper!

This was good chicken and was delicious but the sauce itself was a tad too salty for me and as much as I like ginger flavour, I didn't like biting into the small chunks of it. I served this over mashed potato casserole and it was a good combination, but I do agree the sauce is more suited for rice. I will make this dish again, but I'll be using reduced sodium soy sauce and mincing my ginger to get the flavour without having those tiny chunks getting in the way of me enjoying this dish to it's fullest. Thanks for sharing.

A quick, simple and delicious meal. The flavors of the ingredients really blend well together. Though the dish has a little bit of a kick to it, I could stand it slightly more spicy, so I may add a little extra hot sauce next time (I used Frank's Buffalo Wing sauce). Also, I used ground ginger instead of fresh ginger root, which I'm sure would have made the dish even better. As a previous reviewer said, there will be entirely too much sauce if you double the recipe, however, if you're the kind of person who enjoys a little extra sauce, you may want to make another half a serving, which also goes great over rice.

text:
Wow, this recipe is really, really good! I used ground ginger (because that's what I had on hand) and chicken thighs (because that's what I prefer) but other than that, I followed the recipe as written. If you let the chicken simmer for a bit over medium heat, the sauce definitely gets sticky -- and it's just as good as what you would get at most mid-priced Chinese restaurants. The sauce does pick up quite a bit of heat from the hot sauce, so if you aren't crazy about spicy, you might want to cut that back to 1 tablespoon. Really good and super easy overall!

text:
Was glad I read the reviews first, otherwise dinner would have been wasted food.  Made the sauce separately which made sense in order to thicken properly.  Also allowed for taste test.  As written, it is very salty and kinda of blah on flavor for us. I had cut back on hot sauce (1T on doubled recipe) as 4 year old was eating too.  It was just a lot of strong flavors crashing into each other.  I added a couple pinches of chinese 5-spice, another 1-2 T of honey to sweeten it up and 1-2T peanut butter.  Viola!  After lightly browning floured chicken (another necessity I feel), I added the very thick sauce, tossed to coat over the heat, and put over rice.  I'm still stunned by the compliments from all including the grandson who normally just eats when he likes it or says I don't like it.  Still used 4 large breasts cut up, and doubled sauce because I was putting over rice.  3 stars for the original recipe, as it is a good base...but, I would taste before coating your cooked chicken, so you can adjust if you want.

Ok... so this recipe turned out to be a happy accident for me. I've been excited for days to make it and first ally did today. I followed advice of a lot of reviewers and dredged the chicken through flour after sprinkling with salt and, pepper. I doubled the mixture (minus the hot sauce, 1 tblspn was plenty), and let it start reducing in a seperate pot while Browning the chicken in large pan . I removed chicken from pan after browned and stir fried green, red and yellow peppers and some onion then added it all together and cooked for about 10 minutes until "sticky". I served over rice made with 1/2 chicken broth 1/2 water. Here's where the accident comes in.... as I'm cleaning up and before I sit down to eat I realize that I had actually used terriaki sauce instead of soy sauce! It still tasted great. As always topped off with duck sauce but that's just personal preference.

This is wonderful!  Very flavorful.  But WOW is it spicy.  I used two tablespoons of Sriracha hot chili sauce and my mouth was on fire!  So for anyone like me who isn't good with very spicy food, I'd recommend cutting down to 1 tbsp of the hot sauce.  Even so, this was very, very good!  Thank you for the recipe.

EDIT: If your sauce is not thickening up, you do NOT need to add cornstarch or flour your chicken.  You just aren't cooking it at a high enough temperature.  Turn the heat up, keep cooking (and stirring!) and it will reduce down and be sticky in no time.

Great flavor in this chicken!  Like others, I found that it was sweet & spicy, but not sticky.  This sauce does need floured chicken or added cornstarch to thicken it up, so don't wait for your sauce to thicken by itself (you'll end up drying out your chicken).  Other than that, it's still a very tasty chicken dish to serve over steamed rice with a veggie.  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

text:
Zippy and different. The first time I made it I did add some cornstarch because the sauce wasn't thickening on its own. But the second time I made it the sauce thickened just fine without the cornstarch. This sauce also works great with pork. Oh, and I used reduced sodium soy sauce.  Update: added some grated orange peel for a little different flavor this time, and it was fabulous! 2nd update: I have made this many times now and have yet to figure out why sometime the sauce thickens up just fine, in close to the amount of time stated, but other times it won't thicken on its own. I always use the same pan and burner, so it just mystifies me. I have made this with grated, chopped, and ground ginger, and have decided that grated works best. I usually double the sauce and add chopped fresh brocolli or some stir fry veggies that cooked seperately at the very end, stir just to coat and serve over rice or Thai noodles.

This either deserves more than 5 stars, or I need to go back to other recipes and only give them 4!  I've made this twice in the past week which is something I just don't do! I liked this recipe and give it a 4~5 just for ease. The chicken is not crispy like at the restaurants, but they coat it in cornstarch and basically deep fry it. This sauce mixture is similar to bottled stuff I have bought but way better. I followed the recipe, but used low sodium soy sauce, 1/2 the ginger suggested, and approximately 2 teaspoons of sirachi hot sauce for the hot sauce. I basically fully cooked cut up chicken, in a pan heated with corn oil on temperature 7, with a little salt, pepper, and adobo all-purpose seasoning. Then added the sauce stirring for just a couple of minutes more. I served with stir fry blend fresh vegetables, from tjs, cooked the same way but without sauce. Lastly, I garnished with sesame seeds. I would make this again for ease alone.

text:
The recipe needs some work, so I found it to be better like this.  

Mix all of the ingredients in a ziploc bag or bowl and add chicken.  I also added 1/8 c vinegar (any kind is fine, I used blueberry and it was really good!), cilantro, and instead of hot sauce, I used 1/8 tsp sambal (a little goes a long way, so be mindful of that lol).  I shook the bag and marinated it for an hour.

Then, I heated 2 T olive oil over medium heat and removed the chicken from the marinade and reserved the sauce; then browned the chicken on both sides, about 3 min per side, and transferred to a warm plate.

Then I added 2 medium sliced onions to the pan and sauteed for about 1 min, then added the marinade to the pan.  Brought it to a boil and  reduced to simmer, then added about 2 T cornstarch (combine it w/ 2 tablespoons water and blend before adding to the sauce to avoid lumps).  

I whisked well and when thickened to the desired consistency, then added the chicken back to the pan.  When the chicken was cooked through and coated well with sauce, I added more cilantro and served it over basmati rice.

A decent base recipe, but I felt it needed a lot of tweaking to be great.  :)

text:
This turned out sweet, sticky and spicy.  My husband and I loved it.  The fresh ginger really made this dish.  I followed this recipe almost exactly.  Here's what I did for a perfect outcome.  Dredged chicken in corn starch, omitted vegetable oil (used PAM spray), browned chicken, removed from pan and set aside.  Added sauce, cooked for a minute or two, re-added chicken.  Cooked on low-medium heat for 9 minutes, continually stirring.  I really let the sauce cook down until I got a tacky texture and sauce was sticking to pan.  Next time I will add some pineapple chunks, bell peppers and onion.  Thanks for the fantastic recipe!

The adaptation I've been making using this recipe is amazing, haven't actually tried it exactly as written but here's what I do:

Sauce: leave out the brown sugar, use equal parts soy sauce, honey and Sriracha Hot Chili Sauce, and ground ginger and garlic from the jar.

Cooking: bone in chicken thighs, bake 20 minutes @ 400F with salt and pepper, remove from oven and cover with mixture, back in oven for 10 minutes, remove and turn over, back in for 10 minutes.

Perfection!

text:
This is a good base recipe and we loved the flavors.  I did modify the recipe slightly based on the ingredients I had on hand.  I subbed 2 tablespoons of agave nectar for the brown sugar and honey.  I used Siracha (sp?) as another reviewer indicated.  I also had some Sweet Chili Garlic sauce in the fridge so I added about a tablespoon or so.  I used only 2 chicken breasts (as there are only 2 of us) and dredged them in Cornstarch/Flour/Salt/Pepper before sauteeing them crisp in olive oil (pure, not evoo).  This got the chicken nice and crispy and also allowed the sauce to thicken and get "sticky" quickly.  I served this with crisp sauteed veggies and Thai sticky rice.  Because I used the Siracha, Sweet Chili Garlic and both fresh garlic and fresh ginger, this dish had a bit of a bite to it, but I WILL be putting this one in my recipe box and making again soon.  It was quick and easy and very very tasty...much better than any takeout when you've got that craving for Asian food.

After cutting 4 chicken breasts into chunks, I tossed with about 3/4 cup of flour, salt, pepper and paparika.  I diced about 1/2 med. onion and cooked with 1 clove fresh garlic and about 1 TBSP of olive oil.  I then added the rest of the sauce ingredients and cooked until the thickness I wanted.  I then browned the chicken in a little more olive oil then added to the sauce and cooked until done.  I only added 1 TBSP of sriracha hot chili sauce even though I doubled sauce and it was the perfect amt for us.  I almost forgot, I didn't double the amt of soy sauce either, I just substituted 1/4 cup of water with a chicken bouillon cube instead of an additional 1/4 cup of soy sauce. Slightly spicy and sweet.  Loved it and will make often!

text:
This is a great, quick recipe that takes boring chicken to a new level. More often than not, this is the recipe my husband requests when we have uncooked chicken on hand. I usually make a few adjustments to the recipe. I exchange a generous sprinkling of red pepper flakes for the hot sauce (to me, the vinegar base of the hot sauce detracts from the overall flavor of the dish). I cut the chicken into chunks rather than strips‚Äîthe chunks seem to soak up the delicious sauce better and it's faster to cut chunks than strips. I also usually water down the soy sauce, so it's probably more like 1/8-cup soy sauce and 1/8-cup water, just to reduce the saltiness of the dish a bit.

text:
I made this tonight and am already posting a rating because it was that good. Hubby said it was restaurant-quality and delicious (and he's not one to lie to save my feelings - last night's dinner was "bland"). I doubled the brown sugar and reduced the soy sauce to 3 Tbsp. Also reduced the ginger because I was using dried. With the chicken, I dredged it in a flour/ wheat germ/ paprika mixture before frying (didn't bother with salt, as the soy sauce has plenty), and then removed it from the pan. I simmered the sauce alone for 4 minutes, then put the chicken back in and simmered everything together for another 4 minutes. As the name of the recipe implies, it was sweet, sticky, and spicy. I served it over steamed white rice, and we both ate too much. Will definitely make it again.

text:
This is absolutely delicious. By sheer chance, I made the sauce before I started preparing the chicken, so the garlic and ginger had a nice bit of time to permeate the other  ingredients. I also followed others' advice and cubed the chicken and dredged it in flour before frying. The coating kept the chicken nice and juicy, and the sauce is so pungent that the chicken still absorbed the flavor, even with the coating. I was bringing it to a family dinner and wanted to add some vegetables without spoiling the taste of the sauce (which is perfect). So I made some extra sauce, simmered cubed red and yellow peppers separately in that, drained the sauce from the peppers, and mixed everything together just before serving. I think next time, I'll try adding scallions or onions as well. It was a huge hit. I can't thank you enough for this recipe!!!

This was very good. My husband really liked it, which is a big deal. It was easy to make. I did not have regular hot sauce, so I used sriracha sauce. My family went crazy for this.  Although mine did not get that sticky, and I really can't figure out why! I did exactly what it says.  Regardless, it still was delicious! I served it with rice and it was gone in a flash.   So, I made this again.  I floured the chicken as suggested, and it came great!  I wouldn‚Äôt say it was "sticky" but it was thicker, and everyone loved it.  This will, without a doubt, be on our dinner rotation.  Thanks!

Edit 2016:  I have been making this now for 8 years and I must say, every time I make it I want to drink up the sauce. What I usually do now is brown the chicken in an oven safe skillet. Mix up the sauce and add about 2 tablespoons of cornstarch. Pour the sauce over then chicken and throw it in the oven until cooked. This usually gets us the best consistency. Sprinkle with some sesame seeds and serve with rice and any veggie.  My family still goes crazy over this, there's never any leftovers!

text:
This recipe is very easy to put together, and tastes like I got it from a Chinese restaurant!  The one change I made was: instead of just browning the chicken, I used a cornstarch/salt/pepper/chili powder mixture and coated the chicken with that.  I heated about 1-2 Tbsp of oil and fried the chicken in there, before adding the sauce mixture.  Frying with cornstarch instead of flour gives the chicken that authentic Chinese taste (A trick I learned from the Food Network).   When the chicken and sauce were combined, and sauce thickened, I added sesame seeds for that authentic look. I also chopped some green onions as a garnish after plating.  Thanks for a great recipe, Kate!

text:
This was an awesome recipe! It kind of reminded me of General Tao Chicken that you can get at Asian restaurants. I think that these changes are necessary: I reduced the soy sauce by half, increased the honey by 1/2 tablespoon, and--*this is key*--tossed the chicken pieces in flour (with a dash of salt and pepper). I cooked the chicken at a high temperature until it was nicely browned, and then added the sauce and cooked for 20 minutes at a low temperature. The flour makes the sauce thicken nicely. Lastly, I used Chili Garlic Sauce for the hot sauce, which worked really well. Yum!

This is an awesome recipe! However, I did do some adaptations (thus only 4stars)... Sweet & spicy... yes. But, I didn't wait to boil down to be sticky because I was in a hurry. I actually think that turned out to be for the best: or it would have been WAY too salty (and I didn't salt the chicken). I gave 4 stars: not so much that it lacked in flavor or ease, but because I didn't like the saltiness, the minimal amount of sauce it made, the chicken cut in strips, the lack of veggies in the recipe and the amount of hot sauce. After not boiling down, halving the hot sauce, doubling the sauce, cutting the chicken in to bite size pieces and adding snow pea-pods, mushrooms, red onion, water chestnuts, & baby corns it became a 5 star for our family that will be made again very soon!

I loved this so much but I am only giving it 4 stars because I did make a couple of changes based on other reviews. I used 4 tablespoons of honey, 3 large cloves of fresh garlic, hot pepper flakes (I didn't have hot sauce) and I added a dash of seaseme oil. I DID NOT salt the chicken, I only used pepper and did not find it too salty as others have mentioned. I also found that it needed to really boil to thicken it up and even then I had to add a little cornstarch. I only used two chicken breasts so that may have been part of the reason why. I then threw in some baby corn, red pepper, and carrots that I had already stir fried. It was awesome! I served this with brown rice and it was all gone!

text:
Well this recipe was good.  I cooked mine a totally different way and it turned out perfect, sweet, sticky and spicy.  What I did was I had chicken wings so I baked them in the oven until almost done. Took them out drained the juice than added the sauce.  Only thing I changed with the sauce was I added one tablespoon of corn starch so that it would be sticky also since I double it I ran out of soy sauce for the second batch so all I had was terriyaki soy sauce,which added great flavor.  So than when I added the sauce I let the chicken cook uncovered, this helped with browning the chicken off and allowing the sauce thicking.  So when I put the chicken on one big plate, I added the remaining sauce in the pan on the chicken and it came out perfect (we ate it over rice), also since I double the sauce and only added three tablespoons of hot sauce. Thanks this recipe was great it is a keeper.

text:
My family loves this! I use the same ingredients but different proportions to make extra sauce (3X everything but the soy sauce, ginger and hot sauce [sriracha]), and I keep the chicken and sauce separate.  I coat the chicken pieces in cornstarch, cook them and remove them from the pan, then add the sauce ingredients to the same pan. The remnants of cornstarch help it to thicken. Then we serve the sauce over the chicken (with rice and veggies) right before we eat. Chicken stays crunchy and there is a lot of delicious sweet/spicy sauce.

text:
After reading other reviews, I followed the advice to 'flour' the chicken pieces before searing them.  I added 2 Tb of flour and 2 Tb of cornstarch to a zip lock bag, added the bite size pieces (my knife skills for cutting strips isn't all that great), and shook them a few times to evenly coat them.  I also doubled the sauce ingredients and heated up separately in a small saucepan.  Hot sauce of choice was Sriracha.  After adding the heated sauce to the chicken pieces, it only took 3-4 mins for the sauce to thicken and the chicken was cooked perfectly.  I served it with basmati rice using chicken stock in place of water, and steamed broccoli.  My son who cooks for a living, said the meal was restaurant quality!

text:
I didn't have a problem getting the sauce to thicken up and get sticky. Which surprises me more than anyone because as cooking goes I'm a novice at best. Here's what I did.

I made this using the pre-cooked chicken strips from Tyson. First I browned the strips in a hot skillet with a little oil. Then I poured them out and did the sauce separately.  The only change I made in the sauce recipe was to double the amount of brown sugar. 

The skillet was still really hot, so as soon as the sauce hit the pan it started to bubble and thicken. Then I put the chicken back in, stirred it around in the sauce and everything got thick and sticky.  Tasted wonderful. It had this nice sweet asian flavor with just a little spicy kick on the back of the tongue.  Everything was great. Then I started screwing up, lol!

Like many, I wanted more sauce. Great,  I'll  just follow the recipe and make another batch.... and another. What I didn't  think about was the fact that each time I doubled the recipe I also doubled the hot sauce. So by the time I finished the dish was very spicy. Really good but really spicy. 

So next time I'll double all the sauce ingredients EXCEPT the hot sauce. Otherwise I followed the recipe to the letter and it was delicious!

text:
I made this last night for myself and my friends. After reading the reviews and that some people were saying that the sauce was not thick, and did not stick, i done this to my recipe.
I made up the sauce and added a little cornflour, and heated up the sauce seperately from the chicken in a saucepan on a low heat and continously striring until the sauce thickened slightly. I then dredged the chicken pieces in some flour and cooked for a minute on each side in a frying pan a few at a time and keeping them warm on a plate and covered with foil. After all the chicken had cooked i transfered the chicken back to the pan, and added the sauce, and then continued to heat through for around 8-10 mins, depending on how thick your peices are. The sauce coated the chicken and it was a nice consistency. Everyone enjoyed, and i most certainly will be making this again.....

text:
This is DELICIOUS!! I combined a few tips people gave -
1) I reduced the sauce on a separate pan on medium heat for about ten minutes while I was cooking the chicken , giving it time to thicken before combining everything.
2) I cubed the chicken, sprinkled on salt and pepper, and rolled them in flour. 
3) I seared the chicken on medium high heat in vegetable oil until it was brown and crispy on the outside but not fully cooked, just a couple minutes.
4) I put the chicken on a plate and covered it while I chopped broccoli and carrots, put some salt and pepper on them and put them in the same hot pan to crisp the outsides.
5) Then I combined everything and let it simmer until the sauce was thick and the chicken fully cooked, 5-7 minutes.
It tastes amazing but if you're sensitive to spice maybe cut the hot sauce to a tablespoon, it was pretty intensely spicy (used siracha).

The hubby went crazy over it and said the sauce was sensational. Doubled the sauce and went easy on the Sriracha as others mentioned (about 3+ tablespoons) and may go easy on the honey next time as I found it a little sweet. Just remember to stir it like crazy until it thickens! Served with snow peas and brown rice.

text:
The recipe was delicious! I usually make recipes "as is" before making any changes, but based on other reviews, I wanted to make sure my meal was "STICKY" so I thinly sliced the chicken in long strips and then coated them in CORN STARCH (3-4 tbs) by tossing them in a bowl. I just think corn starch is a better thickening agent than flour. Also, for a meal like this I think SRIRACHA (rooster sauce) is the only way to go! However, a little goes a long way and I added too much, so I ended up doubling the sauce with low sodium soy sauce, but I'm glad I did!!! I don't think the original amount would be enough to coat chicken/leave enough to coat whatever you're serving it on top of/with. I served over rice with some broccoli and it was DELICIOUS! We will be eating this again, and again, and again.

Amazing and easy! Took suggestions and coated chicken breasts in flour; heated the oil very hot. My chicken breasts were thicker so next time I'll start the sauce once I turn the chicken. Once I poured the sauce over the chicken, it bubbled and thickened right up. Preparing the rest of the chicken for a freezer meal!

text:
Had I not made some minor changes to this recipe it would have been far to spicy and I don't think the sauce would have thickened as nicely as it did. Overall this was a great base recipe and my chicken came out fantastic. 2 tbsp. of hot sauce is FAR too much. I'm not sure if it was because I was using Hot "Pepper" Sauce, but thank god I added the honey before the hot sauce because I ended up tilting the bowl to the sink and letting pretty much all of the hot sauce roll off the honey and into the sink because it was just too much hot sauce. I would recommend no more than half a tbsp. if you like it more on the spicy side and add some red pepper flakes while cooking it, which is what I did. I also dredged the chicken lightly in flour beforehand and while it was cooking with the sauce, I cut the chicken into bite sized chunks. The final result was a nice balance of spicy and sweet, and the perfect consistency teriyaki sauce. It was slightly sticky and thick enough to stay coated on the chicken but not so thick that it clumped into a thick gel. I was very pleased with this recipe overall and would recommend using the sauce while cooking some stir fry veggies on the side.

text:
Based on previous reviews, I made the sauce on the side first.  It thickened up just fine for me.  Then, I cooked the chicken and added the sauce to it.  I used chicken thighs, because I didn't have any breasts, and they were juicy and delicious.  The level of heat was perfect for me.  The first bite was awesome, but by the time I got to the end of the dish, I think the soy sauce flavor was just too strong for me.  The next time I make this, I will probably cut back on the soy sauce, like maybe half as much.  Then, I'll taste it and determine whether to add more sugar or honey.  I didn't get much of a sweet flavor, just a lot of heat and soy.  Perhaps cutting back on the soy will bring out more of the sweet and I won't have to add any.  We'll see.  This recipe is a great start, though!!

text:
I would give it a 5-star, but I had to alter the recipe some. Review from "Rebecca" was most helpful. 

---Sweet...yes. Spicy...yes. Sticky...no Very good flavor but I had the same problem other reviewers mentioned about the sauce not thickening up. I will make it again with the following changes: 1. Dredging the chicken strips in flour before sauteing, which will help them brown better and help thicken the sauce. 2. Saute on med.-high heat instead of medium. The heat called for in the recipe is not enough to sear the chicken. 3. Simmer the sauce while I am preparing the chicken, then add to the chicken as called for. Because, it took much longer than 8-10 minutes to reduce the sauce, and the chicken dried out. I should add my husband loved this recipe. The flavors are good. Thanks.--- 

Just be careful to not burn the sauce when simmering (cook on medium to medium-low).

text:
Loved this recipe but I did tweek it although this recipe can totally stand on it's own without any changes.  I do try to lower salt in all of my cooking so I didn't salt the chicken before cooking.  As with traditional chinese cooking I did dredge the chicken in CORN STARCH not flour. It thickens better than flour.  Also used a low sodium soy sauce.  I do like a little more sauce so in addition to the 1/4 cup soy sauce I added another 1/4 cup of water, no additional seasoning.  The result was great... Lots of flavor and the additional water didn't weaken the flavor at all.  Corn startch thickened the dish nicely.  Note:  For gluten free people use corn starch and tamari or amino's in place of the soy sauce.  I doubt you would notice any difference in flavor.  Great recipe and everyone raved about it!  Thanks!

This is so very good. I used chicken tenderloin strips and I used 2 teaspoons of powdered ginger because I never have ginger root on hand and also used low sodium soy sauce (just a personal preference regular soy sauce is way too salty for our taste). For the hot sauce I took other reviewers suggestions and used sriracha hot chili sauce (found it in the international isle at grocery store) I doubled the sauce and used a little extra honey and brown sugar (maybe an additional half tablespoon of each) and used a little extra sriracha sauce. I added a little salt and pepper to the chicken then tossed the chicken strips in flour before pan frying and they had a nice golden brown crust on them before pouring in the sauce I removed the chicken and poured out the oil from the pan, put the chicken back into pan and  poured in the sauce and then added a tablespoon of corn starch mixed with a little water and the sauce thickened up and finished cooking the chicken. I think next time I make this I may cut back on the amount of corn starch the sauce got very thick. I made Goya Mexican rice chicken flavor and added some peas and corn to it and put the chicken on top of the rice and we had a very good satisfying dinner. You wont be disappointed with this dinner, the chicken is juicy and very flavorful thank you for sharing and thanks to all the helpful reviews !

Great reciepie. There was only two of us so I did half the chicken, but used the same amount of sauce. I did 1/2 the hotsauce, added about a teaspoon of garlic powder, and used ground ginger. Turned out perfect. 

I seasoned and cooked the chicken first, in my favorite cast iron, after seasoning it for 5 minutes with onions and garlic. Took the chicken out, added veggies.

Turned out amazing! healthy too after adding so many veggies.

text:
Review update - I make this recipe at least a few times a month.  It is a fast weeknight recipe that I know I can have on the table in under 45 minutes.  Originally I used to dredge the chicken in flour, but I don't bother with that anymore.  You can if you want that nice crust on your chicken.  I use cast iron, so I don't have to worry about not getting a nice crust!  This recipe was seriously awesome!!!  I followed the recipe almost to a T, except the ginger.  I only had dried/powdered ginger.  So I used just a tsp of that. Figuring that the dried would be much stronger than fresh.  I dredged the chicken in flour, salt, and pepper and pan fried in the oil.  I also added 1 diced red bell pepper (saut√©ed).  Hot sauce I used was sirracha (red rooster). Even the leftovers were awesome! Will definitely make this again!!!

text:
My chicken was tender and juicy because I decided to bake 3 (large/thick) boneless breasts in a 11X7 baking dish with minced garlic and sprinkled with garlic salt and pepper. I covered it loosely with foil and baked it at 375 degrees for about 35-40 minutes (keeping the juices to add to the brown rice I had in the fridge). I let them set for about 10 minutes on a cutting board before cutting them in 1/4-1/2" strips and shredding the strips with my fingers into bite-size pieces.

I didn't change the sauce much, but I did double the recipe. I used low-sodium soy sauce, Frank's Thick Hot Sauce and then added a tsp. of the Chili Garlic Sauce with the rooster on the bottle. I also added about 1/4 cup of orange juice.

I cut a red pepper into slices and added some broccoli florets and I threw them into a large hot skillet that I had sprinkled sesame seed oil in (almost enough to cover the bottom). I tossed the veggies around the hot skillet for about 4 minutes or so til the broccoli florets were bright green. Then I added the chicken strips and the sauce and let it get bubbly hot. I then mixed about a tbsp. of cornstarch with a 1/3 cup of orange juice, stirred it until smooth and added it to the pan, stirring til the sauce thickened. Wow! Yummy!
I added the juices from the chicken to the brown rice in the same baking dish and warmed it in the oven while I was making the sauce etc., and it was really delicious when we added the chicken & veggie combo over the top of it.

text:
If I could give this more than 5 stars, I would. Wow. I made it for friends on Friday night. No leftovers whatsoever. Made it again on Saturday night for dinner leftovers for the week. It's now Monday and I have 1 serving left. Made a few changes after reading some reviews. Dredging the bite-size chicken pieces in flour before cooking them really adds to the dish. It almost helps the sauce stick to the chicken more. I sauteed a diced onion until soft then removed and set aside. Then cooked the chicken and removed and set aside, then added the sauce to the pan to cook for a few minutes before adding the chicken and onions back in the pan with the sauce. It helped the sauce thicken and avoided the chicken to be overcooked. I also doubled the sauce ingredients, except for the sriracha sauce (3 tbsp is great - 4 tbsp is a little too much heat). At the very end, I added some fresh uncooked broccoli to the pan when I added the chicken back in. Allows the broccoli to cook some, but stay crunchy. Favorite recipe on this site by far!!

Recipe as written would have been too salty, as others mentioned you need to cut down on the soy sauce.  I also used 1 teaspoon ginger and it was plenty.  Overall this recipe has a good base of ingredients you can tweak.  I used sesame seed oil in place of veggie oil for more asian flavor.  I also left out the hot sauce to make it more kid friendly.  For even more kid appeal I added a little peanut butter.  I placed my chicken in the crock pot and let it simmer in the sauce for a few hours, the chicken absorbed the flavors really well.  I served it over noodles with cabbage and broccoli, the family loved it. You can probably also add some orange juice to give it a citrusy flavor.

text:
After reading that some people said the sauce took too long to thicken and the chicken dried out, I got scared and doubled the amount of sauce. This was a mistake, as there ended up being an excess of sauce (even when I bumped up the number of chicken breasts to 6). Next time, I'd stick to the recipe's instructions for the amount of sauce to use, but also coat the chicken in flour, per other reviewer's recommendation. 

I really liked this recipe for the first couple bites (especially the kick from the hot sauce), but then I started to get salt overload. 

Next time:
- I would still coat the chicken in flour (I used whole wheat flour to coat the chicken and don't think it made a difference in taste compared to using regular, all-purpose flour).
- I'd try using low sodium salt and keeping the 1/4 cup, or halving the soy sauce and adding water. But it was way too salty as written.
- I'd add in half an onion (sliced lengthwise), and 2-3 bell peppers, cut into 1-inch pieces 

This recipe still gets 4 stars because I can tell it's a great base recipe. I'm sure after tweaking it a little, it'll be even better!

text:
Easy enough for a child to make. It seems I did some of the same things others have done to improve upon an already good recipe. I tripled the sauce ingredients except for the soy sauce and added even a little more brown sugar. I also dredged the chicken ( which I got the butcher to cut up into bite size pieces for me; I always look for the easy way to do things) in cornstarch instead of flour. Instead of mincing the ginger and the garlic I grated the one and put the other through the garlic press to add more flavor. At the end of cooking I added some steamed broccoli and served it over sticky sushi rice. It was a sticky, delicious, quasi-Asian meal.

text:
We decided this one is a definite keeper!  Lightly dredged the chicken pieces in peppered flour, then browned.  When almost brown, added a thinly sliced, small onion and cooked until softened, then poured in sauce.  Probably used a little less soy and a little more honey (didn't measure) and 1/2t powdered ginger; it thickened beautifully.  Actually had to finish cooking with the lid on or the sauce would have burned down.  It was SPICY, but I guess the hot sauce you use will determine the heat factor.  We ate with a 'flavored' rice vs. just plain, as the sauce IS sticky and wouldn't have been enough to flavor/sauce rice on its own.

This was fabulous!  I dredged chicken tenders in flour and pan seared in olive oil, only for crispiness on the outside, not to cook entirely.  Then I placed the tenders in my crock pot.  Mixed all sauce ingredients in glass bowl, subbing in ground ginger and 1 shake of crushed red pepper for the fresh ginger and hot sauce, and poured over tenders. Wish I could give this 10 stars! OMGosh this is good!  I did increase the sauce 3x, as I wanted more for the rice. And as per some of the other reviews..I mixed 1/2c flour and 1/2c cornstarch and dredged the chicken in that first, before frying. To make it go a little further, I added about a cup of cashews, a cup of mushrooms, and a cup of sliced onion (after the chicken was done frying, I threw these last 3 ingredients in until the onion was tender) then added the sauce. Great recipe when made just as written and even after adding some texture to it. Thanks Kate!

This recipe was delicious! I made a few minor alterations, I dont like garlic so I skipped that, and I threw in a few other spices I almost always use. As far as the sauce thickening - I cooked the chicken as directed, added the sauce, then removed the chicken and added a little bit of flour to the remaining sauce, it thickened very well, and I then poured the remaining sauce over the chicken, served with rice and vegetables. 

*If adding flour, careful not to add very much, a little bit goes a long way, and make sure to stir constantly

text:
4 star as is, but DEINITELY 5 star with few changes from other suggestions.  (1) Dredge chicken cut into bite-size pieces in flour to aid with crispy outside and thickening sauce. (2) We like hot food. Other suggested Sriracha garlic chili sauce and I totally agree HOWEVER, it is hotter than the avg hot sauce so start with 2 tsp - 1 Tbsp and add more if you like but don't start with 2 Tbsp in recipe until you try it first.  If you're wondering where to buy Sriracha, I can get it in my Asian section at Walmart superstore or Ingles here in NC or of course an Asian market. (3) I added veggies - onion, tricolor peppers, baby corn, minced jicama, carrot and broccoli because I like my veggies. (4) I doubled the sauce to accommodate the extra veggie ingredients. (5) I like others suggested, brought the sauce ingredience to a slow boil in a seperate pan so not to dry out my chicken and let in cook down a bit before adding to the seared chicken and it thickened up nicely.

Im giving this recipie 3 stars as written. But with a couple of small changes, it is easily a 5 star recipie. The first time I made it, I followed the directions pretty much exactly. And it was okay. The sauce did not thicken even after cooking for 20+ minutes.   So the second time, I dredged the chicken in flour, as suggested. I also doubled the sauce, because I had a lot of chicken and some veggies (peppers and onions) to cook in it. But did not double the hot sauce. I used 3 tablespoons. My husband and I LOVED, LOVED, LOVED this. It was a little too spicy for the kids though. So maybe next time I will used 2 tablespoons of hot sauce. Also I used powdered Ginger, only because I was out of fresh, and it turns out just fine that way too.   All in all, this is a tasty and easy recipie. Definately worth trying. And tweaking for your own tastes. And some veggies and steamed rice and you have a great meal!

AMAZING dish for the whole family (me, hubby, 4 year old, and 20 months); with a few small tweaks.  We buy chicken pieces with bone/skin on to save money (yes, its a bit more work to get skin/bones/fat off for nice chunks,  but WELL worth it, never any dryness).  I made this twice & the 2nd variation was PERFECT.  Sauteed mushroom & onions in butter. Meanwhile I coated chicken w/ flour/paprika/pepper/garlic powder mix - shook in baggie, let sit.  Removed mushrooms/onions and added chicken *carefully* to hot oil.  Cooked this for a good 5 minutes for some crispiness! (chicken was NOT dry!!).  Added back shrooms/onions and A dded sauce - all same BUT used terikayi in place of soy, 1T Franks red hot, and 1/8t only ground ginger (its the equivaltend to almost a T of fresh!).  Cooked it for only 4-5 min, got thick just fine.  EVERYONE loved it.  Thanks for this recipe!!!

text:
Really good base recipe, but I tweaked it a bit.  I sauteed green peppers and onions in oil and then put aside.  I then cut the chicken into bite sized pieces and added them to a flour mixture of corn starch, paprika, salt and pepper.  Fried the chicken in oil until crisp and cooked through. Added sauce along with the green pepper, onions and a can of baby corn. Simmered for approx. 10 min. and served over rice. Yum!!

text:
This was sweet and medium spicy, but the soy saltiness was way too strong for me in this dish. Seeing this was an asian type dish I used Thai sweet red chile hot sauce, but then also used 1/2 of the cayenne pepper sauce called for, louisiana style hot sauce. I used ginger paste from a jar. This was good but needs a few tweaks to make it great.
UPDATE 8-2015: I made this again using 2 chicken breasts cut into cubes, and then sprinkled it with a mix of kosher salt, black pepper, and yellow curry powder. Then I coated it with plain self-rising flour and let it sit while I made the sauce and heated the pan. Although I cut the chicken amount in half to only feed 2, I left the sauce amount as is. I did cut the soy in half since it was too much last time and then added in some Sweet Mirin and a little Teriaki to make up the difference. I used Sriracha sauce but cut it back by 1/2 tsp. I used powdered ginger. I tossed in some broccoli florets that I cooked in the microwave and then some slivered almonds and served this over steamed Jasmine rice. What a delicious meal! I love this recipe.

text:
This has quickly become a favorite in my house. As with most recipes, I've played around with it a bit. I always flour the chicken first, which helps to thicken the sauce. I double all of the sauce ingredients - but for the liquid, I do 1/4 cup soy sauce and 1/4 cup orange juice. This cuts back on the sodium and gives it a nice orange flavor in the background. I use sriracha as the hot sauce, which is very potent, so I just add it to taste. I steam some broccoli and throw it into the pan so it soaks up the sauce. Served over brown rice, this is a great, simple meal.

text:
Soooo good. Based on other reviews, the first time I made it I added more hot sauce--we like things spicy, but I definitely overdid the spice--when I put the sauce into the pan the spiciness filled the apartment (and our lungs. oopps). Anyway, so you don't end up unable to finish your meal due to the intense burning in your throat...make it spicy to taste! Trader Joe's crushed ginger and garlic are perfect for this recipe. I dice the chicken breasts and dredge in a flour/garlic salt/pepper before browning (would recommend this), and I make double the sauce. :) You will like this--you can adjust it to your tastes; it's quick and easy and delicious! Oh, and I've used Karo syrup in lieu of honey (ran out); it was fine as a substitute, but the honey adds a slightly heartier flavor. :)

text:
This recipe was AMAZING!! Changes I made: Used 1.5 tbsp of hot sauce, 3 tbsp of soy sauce to start off with. Sauteed chicken separately in veggie oil, then when it was cooked all the way I added the sauce mixture.  The key to getting the sauce mixture right is to keep tasting it and add more of what you think it needs.  If it tastes too much like soy sauce, add more brown sugar and honey. I also added water chestnuts towards the end and they added a great extra touch.  Veggies would also be great in this recipe.  I can't wait to make it again!!

Fantastic! There seems to be some people here that say this is not sweet or sticky. The way I made it, it was definitely both. I tossed the chicken in a flour/pepper/garlic/paprika mix, and some excess flour ended up in the pan. I think the excess flour helped the sauce to thicken better.  I doubled the sauce, as recommended by others (a definite MUST!), with the exception of the hot sauce.  I cut that back because of what some other people here recommended. I felt that it was not spicy enough this way (but I like pretty spicy food). When I make it again, I will add a little crushed red pepper or a little extra hot sauce. I served this over white rice with steamed broccoli on the side. Overall, it's an absolutely amazing meal. Especially since it is soooo easy to make.  I will definitely be making this over and over again. YUMMY!

text:
If I could rate this a 4 1/2 I would - made it for dinner tonight, and it IS a keeper!  The lower rating is just because I followed some other reviewer's suggestions to: coat the chicken strips with flour, slightly brown them, remove them from the pan; add the sauce ingredients and cook until they come to a boil for a minute or two, then turned the heat down and added the chicken to finish cooking and thicken the sauce a bit.  While it really wasn't "sticky", the sauce did thicken nicely.  I did add about 1/2 cup water, initially because there just didn't seem to be enough sauce, but I think it helped to keep the sauce from being too salty, as well.  I did use only 1 T. hot sauce, but added 1/2 t. red pepper flakes, just because I don't like the vinegary taste of bottled hot sauce.  Thanks for a wonderful, quick and easy recipe! (With  a little night-before prep, you could have dinner in the time it takes to cook the rice.)  I served this with sticky rice, steamed asparagus, and fresh fruit; I also sliced a couple of green onions to sprinkle over the top.  It is now in my dinner rotation.

Oh my goodness!!  Dee-lish and so simple. It really did taste like it was from a Chinese deli. My spin on this was to cut the chicken strips into cubes and after reading others suggestions (and I thank you)I coated the chicken in flour  and browned until it was crunchy. I only used two chicken breasts but made the sauce per the recipe. Which makes me wonder if it would really have been enough for four breasts?? It was interesting to read that so many had trouble getting the sauce to thicken mine was perfect after ten minutes. The meat was well coated with a rich sticky caramel colored sauce and the smell was amazing. The only thing I did different with the sauce was to increase the brown sugar to 2 tblsp. which was actually an accident. I also threw in a hand full each of chopped red pepper and green onions for flavor and eye appeal with the sauce. Will definitly be making this again!

Wonderful! Mine definitely turned out as the recipe states - sweet, sticky, & spicy. I didn't have any problems with a thin sauce - it perfectly reduced and left a thick sticky sauce that stuck to the chicken. It did take me about 15-18 minutes to completely reduce.  I used Sriracha hot chili sauce. It is a thicker sauce than most "hot sauces" and has great flavor - but, word of warning it is very hot! You can find it on the Asian food aisle in your grocery store.  I added some broccoli florets to the chicken and served over jasmine rice.  The next day I took the leftover chicken-heated it and wrapped it in a tortilla with some lettuce and a little chili mayonnaise.  YUM!

text:
This was great, but needs some adjusting.  

I added more meat and doubled the sauce to feed our family of four (with some leftovers).  I only used 1 T. of hot sauce for the whole thing (1/4 of what the recipe called for) and it was still plenty spicy.  I can't imagine trying to eat it with an entire 1/4 cup of hot sauce!

I also cut the chicken into bite sized pieces (rather than strips) and dredged them in flour and salt before cooking them.  It made the sauce turn out really well.  If you cut the chicken up like I did, it will only take about 2-3 minutes to cook through.

I gave this five stars because it was SOOO easy and my family LOVED it!  So did I.

I took one peron's advice and lightly coated my chicken with flour (dusted it) and I had to use 1 TBSP of buckwheat honey (stronger, darker and not as sweet as regular)in addition to regular honey since I was almost out. 

It was so easy to prepare and just cooked away as I fixed rice and broccoli.  It does have a kick to it, but I like that and it probably would have been a touch sweeter if I had enough regular honey, I may even add an extra bit next time.

It was sticky, reddish brown, spicy and slightly sweet.  My son said he wasn't crazy about the spicy part but he couldn't stop helping himself to more..I pointed that out to him. 

This recipe is an easy to prepare winner as far as I'm concerned and the fact that it has very little oil/fat in the recipe is a nice touch too.

text:
This recipe would be 5 stars easy if you just change two things: dredge the chicken in flour before sauteeing to help the sauce thicken (and kick the heat up to med-high), and use chicken thighs instead of chicken breasts. Chicken breast strips cannot withstand a saute and then a 10 minute simmer in the sauce while it thickens, and I don't tolerate overcooked chicken. Thighs, on the other hand, handle this method perfectly.  Prepared with these few changes, the recipe is fantastic.

text:
This could be a 5 star recipe if it didn't need so many changes.  I put the chicken strips in a bag with flour, salt, pepper, and onion powder and  shook until covered.  I cooked the chicken on med-high then turned down to med.  I mixed the sauce ingredients together and found there would not be enough  so I did 1.5 x the sauce.  I used ground ginger and put 1.5 tsps, it probably could have used closer to 2.  I put 8 dashes of Tabasco sauce as that is the only hot sauce I have.  I cooked the sauce and tasted it before adding the chicken--it was way too strong.  I added some of the water I boiled the broccoli in, about a cup (but I recommend to add per taste--apple juice would probably work great, too).  Plus I thickened the sauce with 1 T cornstarch in 3 T water after I put the chicken in.  before serving I stirred in 2 cups chopped broccoli florets.  Not bad at all, I plan to make this again sometime.

text:
Excellent!  I followed sauce to a T, however, I have doubled on occasion. I preheated my pan (stainless steel), then tossed cut boneless skinless thighs, (our preference) in around a tbs of cornstarch (makes for crispy chicken), added to oil basted pan, high heat, (chicken won't stick if you let pan get hot enough) tossed around till browned, then added my sauce that I pre-mixed, swirled it quickly in hot pan to coat the chicken.  Sauce will thickened up quite quickly, and let simmer about 5 minutes to finish chicken.  Add a touch of water if sauce is too thick.  Served with fresh green beans and whole grain brown rice. Yum!  I make this often.

Very good. I doubled the recipe and did exactly as followed. The only changes was using powdered ginger and garlic, as I lacked any fresh. And I used low sodium soy sauce. 

This was definitely spicy for me, but not intolerable. If/when I make it again I'm going to use only half the hot sauce. 

It thickened for me. The key may be boiling off the excess water (in the soy sauce for example). It's the same method/idea in making jam. 

For a first time make, I'd say it went over well, just a little too hot for our taste, but no one in the family really complained and it justified eating ice cream afterwards. :)

Great recipe.  Like some of the other commenters, I dredged my chicken which made it turn out tender and made the sauce stick to the chicken really well.  I also added a little rice vinegar to the sauce because I always seem to overdo either the soy sauce or honey initially and it does a great job of cutting whichever flavor I overdid (this time the honey).  We also added some broccoli and shredded carrots directly into the chicken and sauce mixture to make it a full one-skillet meal and it was awesome.

Made it mostly as stated plus a suggestion from the reviews. I fried all of the chicken strips after coating them in flour, salt, and pepper. A little trick is to put those three in a ziploc bag and shake it up to coat the chicken. Then, after I fried the chicken completely, I mixed the chicken into the sauce in a large bowl instead of simmering. Not my favorite flavors (not a big ginger fan), but was a big hit with the family. Overall, easy to make!

text:
This turned out absolutely amazing. I didn't make it exactly how the recipe called, however. I fried the chicken (diced up some thin chicken breast, tossed them in egg white then a seasoned flour) while grilling some white onion slivers. Once the chicken was cooked I moved it over to the pan with the (now slightly browned) white onion and added the sauce. I let that simmer for maybe 10 minutes while mixed it all together and it came out PERFECT. Poured the chicken over a bed of white rice and garnished the whole bowl with green onion and sesame seeds. Freaking. Wonderful. Oh, and I pretty much doubled the amount of honey. Will be making this again.

Coated the chicken in flour and seasined with salt and pepper. 

Doubled the sauce ingredients except for soy sauce. Used a quater cup of soy sauce and added 1/2 cup of Campbell 's chicken broth. 

As i fried up the chicken, i deglazed pan using chicken broth. 

I used 2 Heaping teaspoons of cornstarch mixed with 1/2 cup chicken broth and added to sauce. I allowed sauce to thicken slightly before adding the cooked chicken. 

It turned out delicious with the changes made. With changes, i would rate it at 4 and 1/2 stars.

Very good tasting (and sticky) chicken recipe.  I doubled the "saucy" ingredients and eliminated the salt.  Soy Sauce is salty enough.  Like other reviewers, I dredged the chicken strips in flour (approx. 1/2 cup) before frying.  I used high heat and cooked the chicken strips until they really started to brown, then added the sauce and reduced the temperature to medium low.  I allowed the sauce to reduce (and get sticky) for approx. 15 minutes.  The chicken remained tender and was not dry.  Great flavor.

text:
WOW, amazing chicken! It was soooooo good! I made only a few changes after reading people's reviews. I made the sauce FIRST (which I doubled, except for the hot sauce, I only used 3 tbl, because I had 7 huge breasts). As the sauce was simmering in a separate sauce pan, I heated the oil on med/high in a non-stick frying pan. I then began to prepare the chicken. After I cut up the chicken into bite-sized pieces, I put them in a large bowl and tossed some flour to coat.  I then seared the chicken for about 1-2 minutes on each side. (They are still a bit pink inside.) After they have browned, I put them aside. I did two batches. By the time the chicken was browned, the sauce was bubbly and somewhat thick. I quickly poured the sauce over the chicken, covered, and simmered for only about 6 minutes. The chicken was not dry at all! I served it with white rice and sauteed broccoli. Next time, I  think I'll add more honey  and brown sugar because I didn't detect any sweetness at all.

text:
I know people don't like it when you give a recipe 5 stars and then include the changes that make it 5 stars, but that's what the reviews are for.  I always read the reviews before I make something, but won't even look at a recipe with low stars, so I love it when people take a good recipe and make it better.  I followed others advice and floured my chicken before frying it in a large frying pan until golden, then I added the sauce  (minus 1 T of hot sauce, I love spice, but find 1 T is a perfect mix of hot and sweet) and cooked until it thickened slightly.  The first time I made this I cooked the chicken on a higher heat which smoked up my house and it was hard to control the browning, some was burning while I frantically moved the chicken around the pan.  Now I fry it on a low/medium heat and it browns perfect and when I add the sauce the pan is a nice lowish heat so the sauce doesn't burn.  You may have to experiment with this recipe, but it is worth it. It states that it serves 4, but don't be afraid to add more chicken, there is more than enough sauce.   It is like General Tso's  chicken, but better because you made it yourself.  I serve it with rice and steamed broccoli.  Better than take out.

text:
We read the reviews about the sauce not being thick enough so we battered the chicken with an egg/flour mixture and fried it up a bit with a few tablespoons of oil. We also stir fried some onion, broccoli, belle peppers, carrots and celery to go with the dish. We tripled the sauce and added chili flakes to it and about a cup of water. To finish we added some cilantro and toasted cashews  on the top. The additional water helped cut the saltiness and it had no problem thickening up with the flour which we poured over rice. The dish was fabulous, the taste was great.  One of our favourite dishes!

Delicious! Used other reviewers idea: 
"1. Dredging the chicken strips in flour before sauteing, which will help them brown better and help thicken the sauce. 2. Saute on med.-high heat instead of medium. The heat called for in the recipe is not enough to sear the chicken. 3. Simmer the sauce while I am preparing the chicken, then add to the chicken as called for. Because, it took much longer than 8-10 minutes to reduce the sauce, and the chicken dried out."

text:
Yes, changes! From reading several reviews, I made quite a few changes, and it was the best Asian type meal I've ever been able to make at home.  I pounded the chicken a bit to tenderize.  Cut into strips. I marinated for about 2 hours  in 1 tsp fresh ginger, 1 crushed garlic clove, and about 2 tsp soy.  Like others, I coated the chicken, but I used rice flour instead of corn starch. I cooked the chicken and set it aside. I cooked sliced onions, green peppers, and some celery, set aside, then I made the sauce.  About 2 tsp of rice starch added, plus 1/4 cup white wine and about 1 tbsp of white vinegar, and about 1/4 cup water. This made the sauce very tasty but not overly salty or overpowering.  Hubby doesn't like heat too much, so I left out the hot sauce, but put in about 1/2 tsp chili flakes which was just right for us. The sauce thickened nicely after about 5-6 min on medium high heat. Then I turned the heat down, added the chicken and veg back in to get hot, then served on basmati rice.  Absolutely delicious!  I also had steamed broccoli on the side for a bit more veg.

I did a lot of tweaking this recipe to my family's liking. This is a great base recipe though. I quadrupled the sauce and used 5 very large chicken breasts. I used 2 extra tablespoons of brown sugar, cut the soy sauce in half because I made it before and it was way too salty for my family's taste. Absolutely LOVE this dish but made a few minor changes worth mentioning....After waiting for the sauce to thicken it seemed likely that the chicken would end up over-cooked so, I removed it from the sauce, set it aside in a bowl.  I added about 1-2 teaspoons of flour to the sauce (I didn't measure) and stirred over low heat with a spoon, making sure all lumps were out. The consistency of the sauce was perfect! In the meantime, I fried red and yellow bell peppers in a separate pan and added them to the sauce when I transferred the chicken back. The peppers remained crisp and the flavor of the sauce did not mask the flavor of the peppers.  Served with white sticky rice...YUMMY!

text:
I followed the instructions that Rebecca used. I also added a bit of water to the pan to make sure the chicken didn't dry out. Turned out perfect. For the hot sauce I used siracha and was the perfect amount of spice even for kids. Little ones had a glass of milk nearby just incase though. In case you did not see Rebecca's review the changes would be: 
1) Putting the chicken in flour before putting in pan.
2) Heating up the sauce in a pot before pouring over the chicken.
3)  Use medium high heat instead of medium. You can turn it down to medium once the sauce is in the pan with the chicken.
I served it on top of rice with brussel sprouts. Perfect dinner with leftovers for lunch at work tomorrow!

The flavor of this sauce is magnificent!  I followed other reviewers advice and dredged the chicken in flour first. I had 3 decent sized chicken breasts that I cut into bite sized chunks. I think I may have had too much chicken for the recipe because the sauce disappeared immediately when I added it to the chicken. There was no way to let it simmer as it was no longer liquid at all. It was definitely sticky though. I quickly mixed up a second batch of sauce and added it to the chicken.  The chicken was very sticky for sure. There was no problem with getting the sauce to reduce. Actually just the opposite.  I'm not sure what I did differently than the other reviewers who had a hard time getting it to thicken up. There was no extra sauce for the rice, but that was fine. It tasted delicious! Very sticky, very sweet, very spicy! Just perfect! Thank you for the recipe.

This was really delicious!  I doubled the sauce recipe because the chicken breasts I used were unusually large plus I like a bit of sauce!  I simmered the sauce separately while preparing the chicken (per one reviewer's recommendation).  I also used Sriracha hot chili sauce (per one reviewer's recommendation) as the hot sauce.  I cut the chicken into chunks (again, they were unusually large and strips would have been too big),  coated with s/p and flour.  Saut√©ed at medium-high heat and when the chicken was about done I pour the simmered sauce over the chicken.  The sauce reduced nicely, had an excellent flavor though was a touch too spicy for my taste.  Next time (and there WILL be a next time!) I will only use 3 Tbs Sriracha instead of the doubled 4 Tbs.  Served over rice with steamed broccoli.  Perfect!!!!

text:
I made this for the first time today, and it looked as amazing as it tasted.   I just tweaked a few minor things.  I used ground ginger and jarred minced garlic in place of fresh.  Also increased the brown sugar by 1 tablespoon.  Definitely use sriracha sauce as the hot sauce.  Sriracha is pretty spicy, and the heat was a little too intense for even us, and we love spicy.  Next time I'll reduce the sriracha by a third.  I wanted to make sure the chicken had plenty of flavor, so I seasoned the chunks with a generous amount of salt, pepper, onion powder, and garlic powder.  I coated the chicken in 3 tablespoons of corn starch and mixed, letting the corn starch mixture become like a batter.  I let it sit for 15 minutes or so, while I prepared my side dishes.  When I was ready to cook the chicken, I took the advice of other reviewers and turned the heat to medium-high.  It gave the chicken a good sear, and the sauce thickened and was a beautiful color.  I was so proud of this gorgeous, wonderful-tasting dish!  Give it a try.  I know I'll be making it again!

text:
Delicious! Duplicates that take-out flavor. 
I made a total, one wok meal out of it by cooking broccoli, mushrooms, onions and some orange peel strips - sort of orange beef from chicken. I added some grated orange peel to the sauce, and slivered strips from onion tops. And a few sesame seeds, as I think the main picture shows. My mistake was to cook the vegetables in the sauce while it was thickening - they got a bit too soft. Next time, the veggies will be stir fried separately, and all combined at the end. I thought 2 tablespoons of hot sauce was too much, but the heat blended in nicely during the simmering process. Great recipe!

text:
OK, I decided to make a few changes to the sauce/recipe, and give it another try.

First, I omitted the honey and double the brown sugar. (Had virtually no effect on the overall taste of the sauce).

Second, for this application, I doubled the sauce recipe but only added 3 tablespoons of hot sauce.

Third, I cubed the chicken. Slicing it thinly makes it really easy to turn to shoe leather if you're not careful. Cubing makes browning it a LOT more forgiving.

Fourth, I marinated the chicken in the sauce for about 2 hours. 

Fifth, I mixed some cornstarch in with the remaining sauce before I added it to the cooking chicken. 

Last, I added a nice big handful of dry roasted peanuts. 

I'll be darned if this wasn't a really tasty "almost" Kung Pao Chicken.

text:
liked this recipe. a bit too sweet for hubby - but the spice was great. I used Vietnam chili-garlic paste and doubled the sauce; i coated the chicken with cornstarch. the sauce didn't thicken as much as i like - next time i will thicken it up with a cornstarch/water mix.  i blanched sliced carrots and broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes. then submerged in ice-water to stop the cooking.
I drained the vegs while  I cooked the chicken in a TBL or so of toasted sesame oil and removed it from the pan when finished.
i sauteed green onions, garlic, sweet onion   and mushrooms before adding the  cooked chicken back to the pan. then i added in a handful of peas. Next i added the sauce in and cooked down for a few minutes on medium high heat until bubbling  and thicker than what i started with.  
Served over white rice.

text:
The original recipe may be better, but I took the advice of others to first dredge the chicken in flour.  I do not recommend doing so unless you at least double the sauce, as the fried chicken breading will quickly absorb the sauce as it cooks.  The flavor was actually quite good, but the chicken was too goopy for my liking, and I could still taste a bit of uncooked flour.  I would be more inclined to cook the sauce separately, let it reduce and thicken, then pour it over crisp fried chicken strips.  All in all, a pretty good dish.
