Yum! My husband and I are big fans of simple stir fry, but I'd only ever used the low-sodium bottled sauce.  I hated using processed sauce for something so simple, so I tried this.  I dredged about 2lbs chicken and pan-fried it first, setting aside.  I  sauteed two bags of stir fry veggies in the chicken drippings, then poured chicken back in with triple batch of sauce (thickened with a little cornstarch)and stirred and simmered until it was all coated and cooked through, and the sauce thickened.  I did need to add some water to thin it.  Such a yummy sauce!  Better than bottled, for sure!  Served over brown rice.

text:
This was tasty but WAY too salty. To reduce the salt content, I recommend cutting the soy sauce to 1/8 cup or less and omitting the salt on the chicken. You can always salt it later if needed.
FYI, I used gluten-free soy sauce but I doubt that makes a difference in saltiness compared to regular soy sauce. Also, because I don't like hot sauce, I substituted 2 shakes of cayenne pepper. That's a matter of personal taste, of course, and again I doubt that it affected the saltiness.
We cut up the leftovers and made a chicken salad (adding mayo and celery basically), and even in this form, it was still too salty.
I'd make it again and enjoy it with the above modifications.

text:
This is a great recipe, especially if you are looking to make a quick week night meal!  I doubled the recipe and added shrimp. I seasoned the chicken & shrimp with onion and garlic powder (omitted the Hot sauce; used ground ginger). I like the flavor created by the soy, ginger and brown sugar.  It gave the dish a flavor similar to the sauce used in your favor take out dish, but with out adding oil and the accompanying fat & calories.

I did add a corn starch slurry when I noticed cooking without the lid did not thicken the sauce.  I used 1-2 tspns of cornstarch, and just enough orange juice (about 2 tspns) to moisten the starch and make it fluid.  Then I turned my heat to high, pushed the meat & veggies to the sides of the pan, and poured the slurry into the center of the pan while quickly stirring.  It thickened perfectly. Best of all my husband enjoyed the dish as well!

city:

text:
This is a great recipe. However,  the first time I made it, being experienced with asian style dishes and chicken's tendency to make slop of sauces, I added 1 tsp cornstarch and 1 extra tablespoon brown sugar to the sauce and coated the chicken in flour prior to searing. Turn the skillet to HIGH (not medium) and let the oil get hot. Add chicken and sear, turning over small pieces with a spatula, for a minute or two. Searing is very important here, as it locks in the chicken juices and is the difference in dry chicken or juicy chicken in these kind of dishes; browning does not cut it with this one. Turn to medium and cook chicken as directed, but do not add the sauce yet. Add sauce to another small skillet or non stick sauce pot, and let it simmer a little (not a lot, you'll burn it) until it is desired consistency. If it is too thin, add another 1/2 tsp corn starch, but it shouldn't be. When chicken is nearly done, add sauce to chicken and let cook for one minute. Turn off heat. It will give a result that looks more like the picture and is very sticky. Additionally, my husband dislikes spice, so the second time I made it, I removed the hot sauce and added 3 tablespoons honey and 2 brown sugar. I think in the future I'll add that much even if I return the hot sauce, as it balanced the garlic and ginger more smoothly.

text:
I really liked this recipe and didn't have problems with the sauce. However, out of habit, I did lightly flour the chicken and seasoned with salt/pepper. Also, since I didn't have fresh ginger and garlic on hand, I substituted with tsp ginger, 1 tsp garlic powder. I used 1 tbsp chili/garlic sauce (husband doesn't handle spicy stuff too well anymore). Added some frozen, whole green beans the last 8-10 minutes of cooking. We thought the sauce was great, but wished I would have made more sauce. I'm not sure why others complained about the sauce, but perhaps the little flour I added helped thicken it. Otherwise, I really didn't change the recipe. Good flavor, although it does not taste like an Asian dish. Then again, there's no reference to the dish being Asian, it's just being assumed by the reader.

I followed suggestions, and coated chicken stirfry strips in tapioca powder, then browned in batches (keeping others hot in my oven)   I added some red pepper flakes to my sauce mixture because my husband likes some heat   After chicken was cooked,  about 10 minutes in all,  I returned all to fry pan, added sauce and put my Chinese noodles on to boil, and microwaved my package of stirfry vegetables, everything was done in 3 min after dumping sauce on chicken.  The sauce was enough to coat the chicken and thickened up well   If you want sauce for the noodles or rice you will need to at least double it.  I did not add any salt or pepper,  this was a hit and will be regular rotation through the month. YUM

text:
I've made this twice now, and made two minor adjustments. First, be sure to cook with stainless steel cookware - the chicken will sear nicely and the sauce will become thick and sticky within 5 minutes. (For those who are not accustomed to cooking on stainless, the key is to use quality stainless cookware, and to pre-heat the pan for about 5 minutes to avoid excess sticking.) At the suggestion of another reviewer, I coated the chicken in flour, which made it even better. I  added sesame seeds at the end and steamed some broccoli, red pepper, carrots, and rice. Excellent!

I usually use chicken breasts for chicken cordon bleu or breaded chicken.  This time, I decided to surprise the kids with a new recipe.  I never regretted choosing this one!!! Browned in hot skillet and set aside. I did 2 T brown sugar and the rest of the ingredients the same.  Added those to the cleaned out skillet and reduced to the thickness I wanted. text:
Loved it!! I had to use ground ginger but it still turned out great. Will be making this again and again!

Update: I make this at least once a month. It is one of our favorite recipes! I actually prefer it with 1/2 teaspoon of ground ginger over fresh (I know, I know, it sounds wrong but the flavor is nice and strong).  I sometimes add a little extra of the sweet ingredients.  It works with leftover rotisserie chicken too.  Oh, if you have trouble with the sauce thickening, it may be because you are using chicken with added solution. Drain the chicken juices (after cooking chicken but before adding the sauce).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was overall amazing. My chicken turned out fairly sticky, and did have both the sweet and spicy flavors.  However, I made the following changes based on reviews:
-after cutting the chicken into very thin strips, coat lightly on flour, this will help brown the chicken before drying it out
-minced the garlic and fresh ginger instead of chopping, because it will help it to cook down in the sauce
-use half the amount of soya sauce, as it did have a powerful soya sauce flavor according to other reviews -at this, it still was quite powerful
-simmer sauce in a pot on medium heat while cooking chicken, to make it thicker
-cook chicken on high heat,  not medium
-if you like spicy, add in another tablespoon or two to the sauce while simmering -we like spice, so adding this was definitely a good idea
-pour the sauce over the chicken while it is hot and let the chicken coat in the sauce off the direct heat with a lid over it, for 5-10 minutes. 


I served this over a bed of rice, and it was definitely an amazing addition to the dish. 
Overall, the chicken was amazing and I got tones of compliments from my family after making this. I will definitely make again, and recommend to others!

country:

text:
Sauce doesn't thicken because there's nothing to thicken it. Adding a corn starch slurry would but I didn't because we ate it over rice which absorbed the yummy sauce. 
Instead of hot sauce, which are usually bitter, I added 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes. Also added extra tbsp of honey to better balance soy sauce.
To make super tender chicken and a full meal:
Chop 1/2 red bell pepper, 1/2 green bell pepper and 1 small white onion. Add peppers & onion to skillet on high heat with 1/4c water and cover. Steam for 4 min. Scoop out peppers & onions, add chicken to pepper water on high uncovered til chicken half done. Add veggies back in & sauce. Keep on high so sauce boils to slightly carmelize, constantly stirring. This was the perfect recipe for me. Easy to do, simple ingredients and worked perfectly, first time, every time. I halved the hot sauce, garlic and ginger, and it was just right for my family. The sauce thickens up if you let it simmer long enough - longer than specified. Makes enough sauce for the meat but if you want to pour it over rice, double the recipe. This was the first Chinese recipe with which I could produce results remotely like what you get at a Chinese restaurant. And the sauce is perfect for stir-fried veggies as well.

Family really liked it, but as my husband said, "It was very good, but it wouldn't be something I'd request too often."  I did have to make a few changes based on what I had available. Good recipe for what I had on hand.

text:
Very tasty and easy to make. I listened to other reviews and tossed chicken in flour before frying. I grated the fresh ginger and used 1 tbsp homemade hot sauce and 1 tbsp rooster brand sriracha sauce. I used 2 chicken breasts instead if 1 but added chopped onion, green pepper and mushrooms to ensure the sauce wasn't too overpowering. 
The sauce was exactly as described- sweet, spicy and sticky. I absolutely loved it and my boyfriend wasn't complaining either. 
I do suggest using a low sodium soya sauce in Kikkoman brand, and also passing up the salt in this recipe. 
I served with pork dumpling and brown rice for a tasty Asian inspired dish.

text:
This was delicious.

I breaded the chicken in whole wheat flower and a dash of salt and pepper. Next, I pan fried it in about 2 tablespoons of coconut oil.

After that, I doubled the sauce and simmered the chicken in it until done.

I sprinkled sesame seeds on the chicken.

The hot sauce I used was the one in the cylindrical jar with the red top and the rooster on it. Not sriracha. More like a chili paste. It was spicy--too spicy for our kids, but fine for us. I used only 2 teaspoons of this hot sauce.

DELICIOUS!

text:
I have attempted other Asian inspired dishes, but with no success....until this recipe. I took the advice of other reviewers and put sauce in a small pan to reduce, as it takes a good 10-12 minutes to reduce. I didn't have hot sauce so I improvised with chili powder to give it a little spice. Also, chopped yellow pepper and sweet onion and saut√©ed in oil for 3-4 minutes before removing and adding chicken (placed in bag with flour to coat first). Having the oil heated on high helped with searing the chicken. You may need to add another tblsp of oil after removing veggies. After chicken was cooked through, I added sauce and vegetables to combine flavors. Brown rice from TJ's was a perfect match to the dish.

text:
The first time I made this, I followed the recipe as written.  It took quite a long time for the sauce to thicken, but after it did, it looked amazing!  However, it was REALLY spicy....like my kids and I couldn't eat it spicy.  My husband (who LOVES spicy food) really liked it, but even he thought it was a bit hot.  
The second time I made this, I made the following adjustments:  cut the hot sauce down to 2 teaspoons, I used powdered ginger, and used just under a 1/4 cup soy sauce.  I also added water chestnuts and bamboo shoots as the sauce was thickening.  Serve over a bed of rice.  FANTABULOUS!

text:
Decided to try this out for dinner and wow, it was delicious! I read some of the other reviewers tips and simmered the sauce separately from the chicken for a couple minutes. I also dredged the chicken in flour first, helps to give it a crispy outside which does help the sauce stick better to the meat. Also using sriracha for the hot sauce gives it a nice kick and makes the dish really tasty. Also use med-high heat to get a nice golden brown crust on the chicken. I skimped a little on the ginger, added a little less than the recipe called for. I did add a little more garlic than was called for. Overall if you tweak this recipe or not it's really awesome.

First, let me mention the few small changes I made. One--I used lite soy sauce to help make this dish more healthy. Next time, I will triple it and I think this will definitely be becoming a staple in our house after that.

text:
It was pretty sweet, and somewhat spicy, but not sticky. Essentially the sauce reduces down to the point it makes a thick gloopy glaze that will quickly burn so I guess that is the "stickiness". Knowing some people had issues with the chicken getting dry, after browning, I sauteed the chicken for a few minutes in the sauce so that it got infused with the flavor. I then pulled the chicken out, and then sauteed a mixture of veggies in the sauce afterwards. I ended up adding water between chicken and veggies to make sure the veggies got the flavor, but didn't get a burnt glaze. Both myself, and my two year old son enjoyed the food, and I'll probably make again.

I made this right off the page with the addition of rice floured chicken strips.  I have to be gluten free so use a high quality soy sauce which is lower salt in addition to no wheat.  With Siracha sauce, this would be classed above mild but not up to medium at Thai restaurants that we frequent.  I rate it at 4 stars as is.  My mods include 50% more brown sugar & honey, 1/2 tsp each dry garlic & ginger powder instead of fresh, and add 1 tsp Xa Xiu powder.  I cook the chicken first, remove it, cool the pan a bit, deglaze with water, reduce the sauce, and add the chicken back.  That put it up to 5 stars in my book.

text:
I wish I had read more reviews because I would've done a few more things differently.  It was a good dish, but needs some tweaking to make it to my taste.   These are things that I did...

1. I used TABASCO instead of Sriracha.  Made the dish pretty spicy.  I had one serving, the bf had no complaints.  I will try it with Sriracha next time.
2. I like ginger, so I put more.  That ended up making the dish spicier.  I like spicy food, but this was like "Whoa."  I put about 3 teaspoons.  I'll stick to two.  =P
3. I added half an onion, which was great!  Next time, I will add more veggies like bell peppers and the whole onion.
4.  I will add more sugar.  I like mine sweeter.  I may double up on both the honey and sugar.
5. I dredged the chicken, but probably not enough.  Or I didn't cook the chicken enough.  I didn't get that crunch, but I wanted to stick to a "healthier" chicken, so it's probably better I didn't pan fry it any more than I did.
6. I used low sodium soy sauce.  
6.  I didn't taste any of it until it was served.  I will definitely taste before I serve next time!

I like this recipe because it allows you to do so much with it.  I'm excited to make it again soon.  =)

I doubled the sauce ingredients, and put it on low heat to simmer while I prepared everything else - just give it an occasional stir.  We really like heat, so I used scriracha for the hot sauce, and also crumbled about 4 Japanese dry seco peppers into my sauce.  I cut a red bell into strips and cooked that in a separate skillet before I started the chicken.  Per suggestions from other reviewers, I put my cut chicken in a zipper bag with some flour and shook it to blend before putting it into the skillet, and I think that helps the chicken hold the sauce.  When the chicken was done, I added my cooked bell pepper, poured the sauce over it all, stirred and left it on the stove for just a few minutes more, to make sure the bell peppers were properly warmed.  We loved it!

text:
Tried this tonight, husb & body builder son LOVED it! I used ingredients as written but w/the suggestion to dredge chicken in flour. I cubed the breasts & tossed in a flour & cornstarch combo. Yep, a gummy mess, so I separated the pieces onto 2 plates, sifted a bit more flour over top & let it rest while I finished prep. I sauteed red pepper & onion & set it aside. I doubled the sauce & warmed it over a low flame. I don't think it was the hot sauce, but the fresh ginger that gave it a dragon's bite. Next time I'll cut down on the ginger. I toasted sesame seeds & set them aside, then used the pan to get = parts olive oil & butter shimmering hot & put 1/2 the chicken in the pan. I did NOT throw it in but placed it so there was space around each piece. I cooked it over med high, not disturbing it until the bottom was brown & firm before turning it over. I did not begin to 'stir-fry' until all sides were crisp & the chicken mostly cooked. I repeated with the rest of the chicken after adding more olive oil & butter. Combined the chicken & added about 1/3 of the sauce, cooked & stirred until it was 'sticky'. Added another 1/3 of the sauce, cooked & stirred, then I added the vegetables, the final 1/3 of the sauce & let it cook down just a bit. I sprinkled w/ sesame seeds & green onion, served over plain rice. Next time I'll stir in fresh pineapple at the end & use less soy & some juice. My son used sauce left in pan to cook MORE chicken w/ LandoLakes saute cubes + olive oil-YUM too!

text:
This was quite easy and quick, and really tasty! I put the chicken pieces in a bag with flour to coat, browned them and then did the sauce separately. Went with 1 tbsp of siracha and 1 tbsp of Frank's Hot Sauce and it gave it the perfect amount of kick for our liking. I didnt have honey so instead of two tbsp honey, I just used 1 tbsp of pure maple syrup and 1 tbsp of molasses. That gave it some sweetness and stickiness. I also had a tube of lemon grass paste so I added 1 tsp of that to it too. I had no problem with the consistency of the sauce, it reduced perfectly and then I added the chicken back in and threw in some peanuts. Served it with jasmine rice and green beans. My wife and both kids loved it. Thanks Kate, great recipe!

text:
Quick, easy and tasty! I had boneless chicken breasts, no plan for what to do with them to make dinner and about 30 min to pull it all together. Tried this recipe with some tiny modifications suggested by other reviewers: I did toss chunks of chicken with flour, salt and pepper before saut√©ing in oil in 2 batches on med/high. I removed the first batch to cook the second, then returned to skillet and proceeded to add sauce, stirred to coat and cooked covered for about 15 min on low heat. I had no fresh ginger on hand but did have crystallized ginger so I chopped some up into fine dice and used 2 tablespoons of that along with 1/2 tsp ground ginger. I served it over rice and my husband loved it. Will definitely be making again!

text:
Following the advice of others, I cut the soy sauce to less than 1/4, I used a thai hot sauce 'Siracha' - only 1 tbs, used 1/3 tsp dried ginger. After tasting, it had a lot of heat, too much. So I added more honey. That tasted better. After putting the sauce over the chicken in the wok, I could really smell the heat. So I got out a cutie (tangerine) and quickly squeezed the juice of four slices into the sauce. That made all the difference. Toned the heat and somehow combined the flavors. Not wanting to wait for a reduction and chance drying out the chicken, I put in cornstarch for instant thickening. Really good. Chicken came out perfect, sauce was tasty and no leftovers. I too added sliced vegetables for added color and flavor. Thanks for a great base recipe.

Delicious!! After browning the chicken I removed it from the pan and then added the sauce ingredients (using low sodium soy sauce)  which I DOUBLED. The chicken was fabulous and my family of 5 loved it-almost an impossibility my household!

This is a really good recipe but like others, I did make some changes.  I did dredge the chicken in flour before I put it in the pan.  Before I did the chicken, I browned one large onion in the oil and then removed it from the pan.  I would recommend using more oil to brown the chicken if you dredge it in flour. text:
The taste of this is very good, but I recommend the following:
*Double the sauce, and mix it up in a separate saucepan. *In a portion of the soy sauce, mix in a little bit of corn starch and add to remaining ingredients to thicken. *Dredge chicken in flour and cook in stir-fry until just done. for whatever reason it seems my chicken comes out a lot more tender from the wok
*stir-fry the veggies of your choice and mix in with the chicken for the last step! We used onions and red peppers cut into small squares. Toasted nuts coordinate really nicely too (walnuts, cashews)
*If you do not want it spicy, simply omit the hot/chili sauce. If you don't have fresh ginger, powdered ginger will do. 
ENJOY! This is a meal that is very quick and easy once you have everything prepped.

text:
I made this tonight, and we like hot food, but this was almost too hot to eat... and I used half the amount of ginger and garlic it called for.  I used the garlic and ginger found in the tubes in the produce section.  I used 1 T tabasco sauce and 1 T of chili paste found in the Asian food section.  Threw in some frozen green beans after chicken was cooked but before I added the sauce.  I mixed the sauce in my mini Cuisinart, and after tasting it and knowing I was in trouble added some Agave. I had no problem with the sauce thickening, but I do use a high heat. Served over wild rice with side of fresh pineapple which helped offset the heat.  I would add this to my dinner rotation, but will try cutting back on the chili paste and tabasco until I get a good amount of heat without hitting the blistering mark.

Definately lived up to its name - sweet, sticky and spicy - just like a dish from a good Chinese place. Made small changes per other reviewers: 1) cut chicken into chunks and coated with flour w salt and pepper. 2) cooked chicken nearly through then added sauce which thickened & carmelized quickly (and would have scorched if not on medium heat).  It was *sticky* not saucy which I liked.  VERY good flavor to the sauce. Glad I used low sodium soy though.

I liked the recipe, but didnt love it.  I think with some changes I will love it! Im not a fan of making changes then giving a less than 5 start rating, but tonight I rate it a 4 star simply because it was too sweet for me. For my taste the sauce was very sweet, too sweet. Next time I make this there will be some changes that I can make to cut some of the sweetness. text:
I have made this recipe so often that I don't even look at the recipe anymore.  It is a staple dinner in our house now.  I have made a few tiny tweaks to the recipe.  I, like other readers use low sodium soy sauce and I do not season my chicken before cooking - plenty of salt in the recipe.  I also add a little more honey and brown sugar as I haven't found the recipe to be "sticky".  I have also found that you need to be aware of the hot sauce that you use - some are more intense than others so taste, taste, taste.  I add lightly unsalted or lightly salted peanuts right at the end of cooking.  I would love to add some pea pods and other veggies but I have a picky eater to contend with.  I would suggest making this recipe as is once and then taking liberty with the recipes as you like - the base recipe is very good and worth trying as is.

Next time I make this, I will definitely add a variety of vegetables, as I like crunchy with the spicy and sweetness of the chicken. I followed several reviewers' suggestion and dredged the chicken in flour mixed with the salt and pepper. I then sauteed the chicken in my wok until browned and removed it to a bowl. I then sauteed red peppers and onions until crisp-tender, then removed it to the bowl and cooked the sauce for a minute or two before adding the chicken, peppers and onions back in. For the sauce, I used ginger powder and tabasco sauce, as that's what I had on hand. I also used 2 T of dark brown sugar. It came out with a nice flavor that had just a bit of a kick.

text:
As is, this recipe is good.  I plan to make it again with a few tweaks.  I think it needed less spice, slightly more sweet and a little more depth of flavor in the sauce.  This would be my suggestion; start by sauteing red and yellow peppers with a little garlic in the hot pan.  When 3/4 done, remove from pan and set aside.  Dredge chicken pieces in flour, salt and pepper.  Saute in hot pan until lightly browned.  Reduce hot sauce by half, add some pineapple juice and add some orange zest to the sauce.  I look forward to seeing how this would turn out with some enhancements.

text:
Good recipe. I have an idea, for those of you with dry meat that works for me. Coat the chicken with 2 tablespoons cornstarch, 1/4 teaspoon salt and 1/8 teaspoon white pepper. Let the chicken stand 30 minutes at room temperature. Using a wok makes it easy to cook using high heat. I use a sweet soy sauce which is like syrup (half the sodium content) and helps to thicken up the sauce faster. Up for your consideration try using crushed red peppers in place of the hot sauce and a few chopped green onions for a garnish.  Thanks for the recipe Kate. :) iota

text:
I've used this recipie with chicken and brussel sprouts.  Both are delish!  To cut the sodium I use brags liquid aminos, it tastes like soy but has no added salt.  As other reviewers have commented, you  either need some flour or be prepared to cook the sauce for 20 min on high heat for this to become sticky.  But it's completely worth it.  I prefer eating it with quinoa but it's also good with rice.  If you like lots of flavor and spice, make as listed but add some flour to the sauce to thicken.  This is my go to recipe whenever I crave Chinese food.

text:
I thought this was a great "base" for something my family would eat. since I have little ones under the age of 3, and a husband who is not so fond of spicy dishes, I toned this down to a sweet and sour chicken and it was a huge success. 

My changes were to dredge the chicken in corn starch. Use tube garlic and ginger, to control the taste of the spices as I was cooking, omitted the hot sauce and added fresh veggie's and a can of pineapple tidbits (drain the juice). This turned out to be very yummy! I served over brown rice. 

Thanks for a great recipe!

OK so what I learned from this recipe is that you have to keep your eye on it constantly...which I didn't and it halfway burned. Besides that it rocked! I took the advice of the other posters and coated the chicken first, cooked it, removed it, and reduced the sauce. I put the chicken back in and and it coated beautifully! It got a bit watery again so I decided to give it 5 more minutes while I washed the dishes (yeah, I know, I know) and when I came back it was sure sticky all right...to the bottom of the pan. We ate it anyways and my husband still loved it, although he said he wished it wouldn't have burned. You can still taste the sweet and spicy and BOY was it good...and that's with it being burned. Can't imagine what the real thing tastes like. Can't wait to try again!

text:
This one's a keeper, it's so tasty. I did coat the chicken in flour and was careful to ONLY cook until it was just slightly golden in color.  You have to remember that the chicken still has 10 minutes to cook with the sauce in and you don't want it overcooked.  I added a little steamed green pepper,  sliced carrots and a can of pineapple chunks along with some toasted sesame seeds and served it over jasmine rice. One of the best meals I've made in a very long time. I think you could easily turn it into orange chicken with a little o.j. concentrate and some crushed red pepper flakes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe, substituting ground ginger for the fresh, as that's what I had, and lessening the amount of chicken. It was easy to make and very yummy! I have made a few changes to how I make this now, and my husband loves those even more than the original. When cooking for the two of us I use 1 large chicken breast and coat the pieces in a mixture of flour, wheat germ, ground ginger, and red pepper. It adds a little more heat, makes the chicken brown beautifully and helps the sauce thicken. After the chicken is browned I throw frozen baby sugar peas into the pan and let them cook for about a minute before adding the sauce. When mixing the sauce I increase the honey to 3 tbs, and I have no issue with the sauce thickening correctly. If you're making this for 4 I would suggest increasing the sauce by at least 50% and the honey by 100%.

I made this for my family tonight. I doubled the recipe for the sauce, except for the soy sauce. It was very gingery, so I would suggest that you don't use all of it if you don't like ginger. I served it over rice and with broccoli and asparagus. I will make it again. :) Thanks!

text:
After reading other reviews, I cut up the chicken, dredged it in flour, and browned it in a dutch oven.  I took the chicken out before it was completely cooked and prepared the sauce in the same pan, which I doubled.  After it thickened slightly, I put the chicken back in and simmered it until the chicken was cooked through.  I used siracha hot sauce and it was pretty spicy!  I also served it over Asian Coconut Rice from this site, and I felt like I was eating authentic ethnic food. It was a great pairing!!  I will definitely make this again.

text:
I really liked this recipe.  I used 4 large chicken breasts and the sauce was not enough to actually make a sauce out of!  But it did coat the chicken nicely and had a good flavor.  I didn't think it was sweet, spicy or sticky, however, but I believe that was because of how much chicken I had.  I still really liked it!  I also cut my chicken into pieces and dredged them in flour.  The end result was really good.  But I thought the dish would have been boring without some vegetables and crunch.  So I lightly sauteed carrot and green peppers in a bit of butter and oil.  Just enough to brighten their colors.  What a wonderful addition to the dish.  The crunch and flavor only added to the dish.  Of course, any good vegetable would work.  I also think some nuts would be good as well.  I will definitely be making this again!   Thanks!!

UPDATE DEC 12 2010: I want to clarify that the first few times I made this I made changes like some other reviewers. I floured the chicken first, put the entire sauce over before putting it in oven. That was a mistake, the sauce burned! Did other variations but one day I decided to just follow the cooking instructions exactly and boy did it turn out perfectly! I don't usually have ginger root so I subtitute 1/4 tsp ground ginger and use a few shakes of dried red chili peppers instead of the hot sauce and use no salt because the soy sauce is salty enough. I cut the chicken into chunks though instead of strips. But the sauce always turns out thick, sweet and sticky for me when I cook it per the directions. We love it, it's one of our favorite dishes. Thanks Kate!

Wow this was sooooo good!  After reading reviews, I altered the recipe based on a few other reviews--which is why I LOVE this site.  I used chicken tenders and cut them into thirds resulting in nice size chunks  I then dredged the chicken in flour seasoned with salt.  I stir-fried  a yellow, red & green pepper and an onion that I had left over in some olive oil, then took them out of the pan & then sauted the chicken pieces.  I too used the hot sauce that you can find in the Chinese section of the grocery store- with the rooster on it.  I did not have fresh ginger so I subbed 1 hearty tsp. of dried.  I thought it was as good if not better than my favorites at our local chinese place.  It is spicy, but not too spicy. This one goes in my favorites!!!

text:
Dredging the chicken in flour seasoned w/ your choice of seasoning (I used Montreal Steak Seasoning, but just a little bit) is a must to get crispy chicken pieces.  I preheated a dry cast iron pan on med. high heat until it just started to smoke, added canola oil and then the chicken pieces, cooked until very browned.  Add the sauce and let boil for a minute or two, reduced the heat and cooked until sauce thickened and became very sticky.  This is very good and you can add green peppers, onions, mushrooms, whatever you like, serve over rice or quinoa.

text:
I made this for dinner today and it was awesome!  My family loved it and so did I.  I followed the recipe as written and made these changes:  1. Added 1 t. crushed red pepper flakes & 1/2 t. cayenne pepper for additional spice. 2. I doubled all the ingredients of the sauce so there would be more on the chicken and since I was serving this over Jasmine Rice. 3. I dredged the chicken strips in flour and only let them brown...I did not cook them until done. 4. I did not add salt...it didn't need it with the hot sauce and soy sauce. 5. I let it reduce over low heat for about 15-20 minutes.  It thickened wonderfully and was all that the title implies: sweet, sticky & spicy!  Great recipe and one that my family is already asking for again! Thanks Kate!

text:
I like the basic idea of this recipe but I've been playing around with it to fit the tastes of the people around my table.  I lightly flour and saute the chicken. I combine the sauce and simmer it to thicken before stirring it in the chicken. It will thicken more when it combines with the flour on the chicken, getting the recipe to the sticky texture I love.  I agree with others that Rooster sauce is a must but everyone around here disagrees on how much so I try to find a happy medium.  Also to make it a meal, I roast or grill some red bell peppers and onion and leave them crisp-tender, stirring them  in at the end. If I have them on hand, I toast sesame seeds and toss them in as well. I only cook Jasmine rice and think it's aroma and flavor works great with the spicy chicken. Yes, this is easy.  Works well with boneless thighs or breasts.

Let me tell you it was so tasty and I got rave reviews all around.  I am thinking of trying it with the chicken breasts next time and not battering it to see what happens.  The sauce was complete magic!

text:
I usually skim through others' opinions to get ideas on the recipe, and I'm glad I did. I doubled the sauce measurements and it was barely enough for 3 chicken breasts cut up, and I'm not a big fan of a lot of sauce so it was just right. I used chili garlic sauce and extra brown sugar to offset the saltiness of the soy. I also made a cornstarch "roux" (1 teas. to 1/4 c. hot water, mix well and add to sauce and simmer awhile). Next time I will use low sodium soy instead. It turned out wonderful over white rice. It's definitely going in my keeper file.

text:
This chicken was amazing!  I found this recipe today when I was trying to decide what to do about my plain old bonless chicken breast that I was planning on serving for dinner tonight.  I was in the mood for something different but didn't have a clue how to get there.  This was exactly what I was looking for!  I followed a suggestion left by others and tossed the chicken first in a zipper bag with some flower.  I also didn't have fresh ginger so just used jarred and it still came out incredible!  My sauce thickened nicely and I threw in a bag of frozen broccoli right into the mix when it was done and heated through.  Way better than the local Chinese place because I knew I had made it with my own fresh, well-trimmed chicken.  I also took some chicken out of the pan after it browned to serve my young kids, before I added the sauce.  So nice not to have to make two different meals!

I was torn between a 4 and 5.  Definite 5 on taste, so I did go with that, but as other reviewers said it really is a thin sauce that needs some work.  This is suprising as when you're mixing the sauce it seems quite thick, then when you pour it on and heat it it turns very thin.  Still, I just brought to a boil a couple times and reduced and it turned out to an acceptable thickness.  Dredging the chicken in four is not a bad idea either.  Also, I only had Tapatio which I didn't think would taste great for a hot sauce so I used Korean hot chile paste instead and it was GREAT.  I will definitely add this to the rotation, thank you!

This is, hands down, one of my FAVORITE recipes. There are a few things I changed, though. I used 1 tsp. ginger and garlic powder to taste in the sauce. I also doubled the sauce because it was not enough for us. Also, after cooking the chicken, I only poured half of the sauce in with the chicken to coat it, transferred it to a bowl and then cooked the rest of the sauce alone and added a little bit of cornstarch to thicken it up a bit..you have to watch the sauce carefully though because it burns easily. We also served it with pasta and just mixed it all together. Very good with either pasta or rice. Thanks for this recipe!

This was really good...here's what I did: I used the sauce as a marinade for about 4 hours. Then I dredged the chicken (I used boneless/skinless thighs) in flour, whole (didn't chop into strips). I seared them about a minute a side in hot olive oil, then turned the heat down to low, covered them, and let them cook 4 minutes. Then I flipped them, poured a little Yoshida's on top, and let them cook another 4 minutes, covered. They were REALLY GOOD.
